thread.title: Lawyer: Author's daughters in Louisville allegations were not underage
thread.title_full: Lawyer: Author's daughters in Louisville allegations were not underage

title: Lawyer: Author's daughters in Louisville allegations were not underage
text:

Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Lawyer: Author's daughters in Louisville allegations were not underage Josh Peter, USA TODAY Sports 8:08 a.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Katina Powell's attorney Larry Wilder. (Photo: News and Tribune) CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LOUISVILLE — A lawyer who said he represents Katina Powell — the woman who claimed a former employee of the University of Louisville men's basketball program paid her and her daughters to have sex with recruits — said Powell's daughters were not underage when they engaged in illegal activities. 
Larry Wilder, a criminal defense attorney in Jeffersonville (Ind.), said Powell retained him because of concerns she could face criminal charges based on allegations involving her three daughters in her book, "Breaking Cardinal Rules.'' 
In the book, Powell wrote extensively about parties — which took place between 2010 and 2014 and involved sex — for which former Louisville staffer Andre McGee allegedly paid her thousands of dollars. Wilder said Powell cannot be prosecuted because prostitution is a misdemeanor with a one-year statute of limitations that has expired. Report: Ex-recruit JaQuan Lyle confirms Louisville escort scandal 
"The book does not indicate that any of her daughters were not of legal age to undertake the activities they undertook," Wilder told USA TODAY Sports Wednesday 
When asked about the matter a week ago, Louisville prosecutor Tom Wine told the Louisville Courier-Journal that if his office receives "credible evidence of … criminal activity involving minor children, we will vigorously prosecute those responsible for those crimes." 
Wilder said public statements and allegations about Powell facing possible criminal prosecution led her to Wilder. 
"She felt compelled to have an attorney that would be able to advise her in that regard," said Wilder, who works near Louisville. Indianapolis writer details Louisville basketball escort scandal 
Efforts to reach Powell and her daughters were unsuccessful. 
Wilder said no official representing the government or law enforcement has contacted him or Powell about a possible investigation. 
"Potentially the government has come to the same conclusion that we have," Wilder said, "that the facts don't support this perception, or this perpetuation of this belief, that there were minors involved in illegal conduct. 
"Based on the facts, none of those daughters were underage at the time they engaged in conduct involving Mrs. Powell, involving all of these folks who are up in a hornet's nest." 
Wilder said he spoke to Powell and the book's co-author, Dick Cady, but declined to comment on who else he might have spoken with.
